reviews.review:
I definitely recommend Shofner over other professors. She is passionate about the materials as well as teaching. Very approachable during class and office hours. She does go through the slides VERY quickly and would sometime skip materials that would be on the test later. She does drop the lowest test grade and her tests are like most other BSCI 160 tests.
BSCI 160, like many BSCI courses, has a lot of materials to memorize and to understand so be sure to keep up-to-date with the material.
goes extremely fast, take schofner for 160
Such a great professor! You can really tell how passionate he is about the material and is eager to talk during his office hours. The work load was very manageable too. Don't hesitate to take him.
Nice professor. Exams are straightforward.
Amazing lecturer. Makes this class very interesting even if you're not a Bio major.

Dr. Shofner is a very sweet person, and it's obvious that she cares about her students and is really invested in the subject. That being said, I took BSCI160 with her in Fall 2020 and it was one of the worst classes I took that semester. The class was unfortunately asynchronous, and while I can't blame her for that decision, she did not adapt to the format well at all. For one thing, she did not have a syllabus, which was incredibly annoying, and instead had all material on her lecture schedule on ELMS. The problem with that is that this lecture schedule wasn't very well put together, it was incredibly disorganized and made it difficult to locate assignments sometimes. She would also sometimes post more than one lecture video for the day, exceeding the time that the class was originally meant to be. She hosted office hours during these originally scheduled class times, so you either had to watch her lectures before her office hours (and sometimes she wouldn't even upload the lectures until late in the afternoon) or hold onto your questions until the next time she had them. The lectures themselves were even more disorganized than her lecture schedule. They were not structured well and seemed to jump back and forth between broader topics and more specific topics. It's hard to truly explain how bad these lectures were, but it was very frustrating trying to take decent notes from them. The bulk of the assignments for her class were LAs (Learning Activities) and her worksheets. The LAs were super, super easy group assignments that were never an issue, and the worksheets were larger assignments that were probably better at teaching the subject than her lectures were. She didn't have any quizzes and would often have extra-credit activities that could get you a few additional points. She also technically assigned textbook reading, but since the textbook is an overall biology textbook, the readings would often go much more in depth than what was being taught in the lectures and didn't always line up that well; I stopped reading the textbook about a month in. The class had three midterms, with one being a week before the final exam. She drops one of the midterms and the final exam is optional, which was nice. Definitely study for the midterms! They were genuinely a little challenging. 

Again, she definitely cares about her students and wants them to succeed. I somehow got an A in this class when I was bordering between a B+ and an A- for almost the entire semester, so it's not a difficult class to succeed in. But, if you're very "Type A" like me, this class might also prove to be pretty frustrating with how extremely disorganized it is. I'm literally an Evolutionary Biology and Ecology major, so I find it impressive that she managed to make me hate this class.

She is such a sweet person. I got very sick with COVID last semester and she was more accommodating and worried about my well-being more than all of my other professors combined. Her tests are pretty straight forward. Definitely go to her office hours if you have any questions, especially on the exam. She is very understanding.

I really enjoyed Dr. Shapiro. He had hands-down the most well organized class during my first semester in COVID online classes. He tells you every upcoming due date at the beginning of every lecture and lets students watch lectures at their own pace. The exams were exactly what was taught. As long as you listen to the lectures and complete the assigned LaunchPad activity you will be fine. You do not need to infer anything or do supplemental learning outside of what he assigns. I really appreciated having him as a prof for BSCI160 when most of my other classes were so mixed up and unorganized.

Very, very boring. If you do not have a passion for ecology or evolution, I do not recommend taking this class. It was extremely hard to stay awake in this class, let alone take notes that are useful for the exams. Dr Shapiro is knowledgeable and passionate about the topics covered in the class, but he is not very personable and his lectures are often confusing.

Dr. Shapiro is a very intelligent professor who really has a passion for teaching. He does give plenty of notice when things are due. HOWEVER, lectures are basic lecture styles off slides and are very boring. The worst part is the homework/launchpad/quizzes which is also a ridiculous amount of work for the level of class this is. Would definitely not recommend taking this class.

Bruns is an amazing lecturer with a real passion for the things she teaches. She often integrates her own research into the lecture information and provides many different examples that make the content both easy to understand and retain. She makes this class very interesting with her enthusiasm for the subject and her exuberance for specific phenomenon is invigorating! She is very understanding and grades come back quickly (homework set grades within a week, exams within 5 days and frequently within 3), and she drops lowest midterm and quiz grades. Overall, I highly recommend Bruns for BSCI160

Although her assignments are relatively easy, as well as the homework. She hasn't been present for any of the lectures for this semester and has had a sub. The sub goes too fast, and is a bit difficult to understand, but her exams are okay as long as you understand the material completely.

DO NOT TAKE BSCI160 WITH THIS PROFESSOR. I was expecting to take a different professor who had the highest ratings for this class and instead was stuck with Dr. Ngeve as a "guest lecturer". She is very hard to interpret as she doesn't understand what she's saying. Going to class doesn't help. Thank god our professor who we were supposed to have had recorded lectures because otherwise everyone would be failing the class. The numbers of people coming to class started getting lower day by day as people started realizing the lectures were online and were less time than the class itself. The one time people actually come to class is when we have our group "activities" which has nothing to do with the lecture. On these days the professor lectures for about 10 minutes and tells us to finish the lecture at home. Then she gets up and leaves before anyone can ask her any questions about whats going on in the class. Every week we have a 10 page assignment which is impossible to do. If we didn't have the previous professors lectures no one would be able to complete them. Any time Dr. Ngeve tries to engage the class by asking a question she gets nothing but blank stares across the room. Even the front sitters can't answer. When someone finally has the courage to raise their hand and attempt to answer she just responds by saying "interesting thought, does anyone have another answer?". Then when she finally says what the right answer is she doesn't explain why it's right and moves on. Also, don't bother asking any questions cause she won't have answers to them. During her lectures she skims through the slides, doesn't explain them, and still manages to not get through all of them. The exams are impossible to finish in time. We have 80 multiple choice on a scantron and and short answers on top of that. The graders are looking for exact wording from the slides and enjoy taking points off by missing a single word even if its synonymous. She gave us an exam 2 days before finals week. There's also no curve in the class and the averages for the tests are in the 60's. She claims she gives us a lot of extra credit but she really doesn't and the extra credit isn't enough to actually get a good grade. AVOID THIS PROFESSOR AT ALL COST!!!!

she does this thing where she goes over review or easier topics slowly, blames the class for going slowly, and then goes through the rest of the lecture really fast and makes it really hard to understand the topics shes going over. however, she did take our feedback and improved a little so i give her credit for that.

She was a really nice professor, she just tends to talk really fast. Since she goes fast, she sometimes skips material. However, she always highlights the most important stuff in a lecture and posts all lecture slides.

Bruns is clearly very passionate about ecology, and does a fantastic job teaching it. Her lectures are easy to understand and usually have a couple clicker questions for easy participation points. Quizzes and exams are very fair, especially since we get a full page of notes to use on the exams. She drops the lowest quiz and exam, which can be a midterm OR the final. There are a few projects throughout the semester, one of which is a group project about different ecosystems, but grading seemed pretty lenient. 
Bruns is by far the best choice for 160.

Dr. Ngeve was a really great professor. She filled in for Dr. Shofner and was able to explain the material well while also taking the time to answer questions. She did talk a little fast initially but adjusted her pace after we mentioned it to her. She is very accessible and also responds to emails quickly. The class also had plenty of extra credit and exams were often curved by 10-20 points. I really recommend taking her because she explains otherwise complicated topics really well. You will still have to study and memorize a large amount of material throughout the semester, so be prepared, but like any biology class, repetition of the material will help you be successful. Don't let negative reviews discourage you from taking her, because you can't expect to receive a good grade after not putting enough effort into the class and then blame the professor for it. HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS PROFESSOR!

Dr. Ngeve was an understanding professor and was pretty approachable. The lecture slides were posted so if you missed information in lecture you were able to go back and we were allowed a notecard on each of our exams which was very helpful as you did not have to memorize specific examples from the slides or difficult concepts that you just couldn't get before the exam. The lowest exam also got dropped and some exam questions were extremely similar to the group activities we did in class. Overall, I thought grading was very fair and we often had exam reflections that gave us extra points so it is very possible to do well in this class as long as you also put in effort since there is a lot of information covered in this course.

This professor is probably the worst professor teaching at UMD. Her slides are filled with text that doesn't even make sense. I cannot begin to explain how horrible trying to understand what is on her slides is. Do not take this professor if you have other options.

Genuinely don't know how she was hired - UMD please fire her
- fast, confusing, slides out of order, commonly makes mistakes then says " idk how that got there" even though she made the slide
- rude: whole class is failing tests she's acts like she's wants to help and has us take a survey, then posts our replies in her lectures and tells us we are dumb and its our own fault for failing
- doesn't know English well
- says kahoot/tophat/moblab (online question forums to test knowledge during lectures) are too advanced for her and will take years to understand and use

only way im passing this class is through the hours of EC assignments I have to do each week
The exams are fast-paced and excessive, the homeworks are graded harshly, and the weekly workload is excessive for a 100-level class.
she is accomodating and nice when you need help or with homework assignments. A lot of extra credit opportunities. class material is not the easiest though.

Nice and understanding professor. The class has a lot of information so missing class is detrimental if you actually want to retain the info. Exams can be difficult are a hit or miss type fashion of questions with some worded strangely. She gives lots of extra credit but the homeworks are graded unbelievably harshly and most likely will be the main reason for your grade drop.

Dr. Negeve speaks very quickly and her lectures are fast paced. The textbook was extremely helpful in this class and clarified topics from her lecture. Be aware that this course requires lots of work, but the more work you put in the better grades you get.

you can tell she really enjoys teaching and loves what she teaches
but i don't lol so it was kind of boring
she explained well and used examples that apply to things we know, but sometimes the lectures were very boring
she also posts an accurate schedule along with lecture videos but not going to class bc its boring = not wanting to watch the lecture videos bc they're boring..
overall good professor in terms of knowledge and explanations, just a boring class in general imo

Dr. Ngeve is one of the most caring professors in the entire biology department at UMD in my experience. She makes a huge effort to make the material easier to approach and digest. She also gives a ton of bonus opportunities which can make up for the exams. I think her exams are very fair, but it's still a memory based science class so it is what it is.

I really like Dr. Ngeve, but I struggled a lot in this class. My grade is average, but I am used to excelling in these subjects. I felt that I could learn the content more when I taught myself/ went over the review pages to understand what would be on the exams. I would go into exams very confident, and walk out feeling crushed. The exams are very long, and complex. The wording of many questions is hard to understand, and the short answer questions take up so so much of your 1 hour long exam. Overall, I learned a lot and appreciated all of the extra credit opportunities provided, but it’s not conducive for someone with test anxiety.

Dr. Ngeve cared about her students and their success, but the lectures are difficult to follow and you have to listen because the important information is not on the slides, and sometimes she does not even go over necessary information-you have to look it up yourself. The exams were difficult because it is a lot of random information questioned that you wouldn't necessarily know to study. She provides opportunities for extra credit which are very nice and dropped one exam. I have been a straight-A student all of my life, but struggled in this course due to the teaching and exam styles.

The lectures were a bit slow paced for me but that will always be different for different people. I would say as long as you are willing to ask questions, Dr. Ngeve will always help you and clarify things. If you don't ask questions then she can only assume that you understand. There are lots of extra credit opportunities and I may even end with above a 100% in the class since I took advantage of those. If you complete all the assignments (yes, they are tedious), I would say you really don't even have to attend lecture. Doing well on the assignments indicates that you will probably do very well for the tests. The tests are quite fast paced, but you are allowed to bring a notecard with any information you wish. Lost 1 star because if you are someone who learns from just the slides, you will probably struggle a bit -- you have to understand concepts in this class (meaning if you only look at the slides you will not know what is truly being taught and will probably not do well unless you have a lot of previous knowledge that you can draw from, which is why I would actually recommend doing all the assignments and extra credit over going to lecture).

Chill professor but the material is overwhelming. Please review the lecture slides as much as possible in your free time or it's hard to get a good grade in the class. Dr. Ngeve also gives an ample of extra credit which boosts your grade up a little if you do all of them.

Dr. Ngeve is a great professor. You can tell she really cares about how the students perform in the class, she was always willing to take student feedback and adjust due dates throughout the semester. All of the PowerPoint and lecture recordings are posted on the course page so if you miss a class you can go back and rewatch the lectures (however the PowerPoints do not always have all the information you need and sometimes it will only be in the lecture). I took BSIC160 and the exams are hard. I attended every class and still struggled to remember all of the information. If you don't need BSIC160 I would not recommend taking it as a gen-ed.

Dr. Ngeve tried very hard to make the material easy to understand and while there are a lot of assignments that can feel tedious, they were very helpful in learning the material. It's also helpful how many bonus opportunities she gives. It's a class that if you put effort into there is no doubt you will succeed. Her lectures are fast paces and exams are tough but rarely unfair.

Thisclass wasn't too difficult, definitely not organic chemistry level difficult. Professor Ngeve cared about what she was teaching about and even more so, cared about her students. She gave lots of opportunities for extra credit. I wish she would slow down a little during her lectures because the material is pretty heavy so that students would have time to process it.

Dr. Ngeve is a professor who will provide you with multiple opportunities to succeed. She is very understanding. However, in terms of lectures, she is not the greatest. Her lectures are slow-moving, and she does not elaborate on terms that you would think are important. She often times would ask students what they think a term or idea was, and then wouldn't add anything original to it and use the students definition, which is not the definition we are tested on. If you are good at Bio in general, Dr. Ngeve is a professor you could be fine with taking, but if not good luck.

Dr. Ngeve is one of the most caring professors I have met at UMD. She really cares about her students and improving her own teaching. She frequently asks for feedback from her students, spends a lot of time answering questions, responds quickly to emails and is looking out for students. She could improve in the organization of her lectures. They usually are kind of hard to follow and don't seem to be in the most logical order. My suggestion would be to look over the slides and textbook after class and rewrite your notes in a way that makes sense to you. Unfortunately, she does not give old exams or practice tests made by her so its difficult to know what will actually be tested on and questions are sometimes ambiguous.  Do not even bother with the TA's practice test they are abysmal and she has no idea what she talking about. There is a lot of extra credit given and I would recommend doing as much of it as possible because it can sometimes give you an idea of what will be on the test and is a good buffer against some of the ambiguity. TIP:  all of the LAs + pre and post are extra credit.

Dr. Ngeve is really kind and nice to work with, but her teaching style is not my favorite. There are a lot of lectures and subunits to study for per each exam, which screw over my grade. The study guide is just a sheet with the lecture summaries, which is not helpful at all. The exams are in class and online, but they've brought my grade down quite a bit because there are no study suggestions. The class average was a C on one of the exams and she blamed the students for not succeeding instead of trying to change things about her teaching styles. I'm not sure why we have to write our suggestions for improvements in surveys because they are never applied. I will spend a long time writing about what I think should be done better in class, but then she says that no changes can be made in her teaching style.

She's a great teacher. BSCI160 is basically a weed-out course so a lot of people are gonna be mad about how they did, but she teaches the subject very well. I hardly read the textbook, just took a lot of notes from the class lectures, and did well in the exams. (The TA review sessions are also an absolute must for highlighting areas you don't know very well.) Also a lot of small extra credit opportunities at regular intervals.

Dr. Ngeve was very good at explaining material and was very thorough in her explanations in lecture recordings. The only reason I'm doing bad in the class is because I always forget to do assignments on time. Other than that, the class is a little hard since there's so much information to process, but other than that Dr. Ngeve was very good.

Dr.Ngeve is very straightfoward. On the first day of class, she told everyone that in order to succeed we must put in the work. She offers extra credit opportunities which I found to be very helpful. You can earn up to 1-5 extra credit points per assignment, Doing these really helped my grade and she also drops the lowest exam. Exams are also a little difficult. For me it was too many questions for the specific time limit, I would recommend going to the review sessions which the TA offers and learning how to answer the questions quickly as possible.

I think Dr. Ngeve is a really nice professor and is very knowledgable about the class, but I think the exams are the most difficult part of the course. They are really long and you have to rush through the questions. I'm a senior, so I am used to this type of testing environment, but I think this would have scared me as a freshman. The extra credit opportunities were very beneficial though. Overall, I would recommend her to others, but just make sure you study the material enough to have a solid understanding before exams.

Not a very engaging professor, lectures are long and almost not worth your time, better studying the lectures for yourself as most of her exam material will be about the lecture slides. Different teaching style, though she is forgiving as she does provide extra credit and one dropped exam. The concepts taught in the class are on par with what you would learn in high school biology, though I found myself struggling in this class.

Dr. Ngeve is a good teacher and it is obvious that she cares about her students' success. I personally learned the most by attending class or listening to recorded lectures on ELMS. However, the course covers a lot of information in one semester and the exams are difficult. The open-ended questions on the exam are extremely time-consuming, as you often have to show your work by typing long equations in addition to your answers. This made it difficult for me to finish most of the exams on time. As someone who doesn't plan on going into the sciences, I would only recommend her course to people who are truly interested in ecology and evolution.

Ecology and evolution are subjects that have always interested me and still do, but this class really took the wind out of my sails. I like Dr. Ngeve as a person, but I personally could not connect with her teaching style which is nobody's fault, it's just the way it is. I didn't attend class for almost two months because this class was at the top of my "Stress Inducers" list, as there was just so much information to obtain in so little time. I think this course is definitely too work heavy and demanding to be a 100 level course; the minimum of at least a 200 level course. I am barely passing this class, and my passing score is mostly due to the extra credit assignments I spent a lot of time on that I could have been doing other work. I recommend this course to anyone who thinks they can handle the workload, and usually I am one of those people, but I took 17 credits this semester and didn't think much of it as most of my courses are supposed to just be gen. eds., but this class was a lot to handle. The exams are incredibly difficult, as they usually consist of asking questions on a bunch of random information, so I can only say good luck when taking them. The homework assignments were also not easy, again centering around random questions that had to do with the lectures but indirectly. If you take this course, I wish you the best of luck and hope you can connect with the professor's teaching method.

Dr. Ngeve is a great professor, She is really nice. I struggled at the beginning of the semester and she offered to help. I am also international so she provided good resources and study session that can help me. She gives a lot of extra credit, she answers quick her emails. I would definitely take her again. the final is open note, she literally want everyone to pass with a A. As long as you do everything as asked for, you will get an A. I am expecting a B+ because I didn't study properly on my exams. thank you
-Laetitia

Dr. Ngeve is a great professor and one can tell she actually enjoys teaching. There is a lot of information to cram into a semester however. The tests are all on your computer , in class, so the math questions are difficult to do in this format.

Dr. Ngeve is a very kind professor who cares about her students, but I found her lectures difficult to learn in. Her slides are difficult to study and she puts really specific questions on the exam. The exams are almost entirely memorization and hardly conceptual at all. She will provide extra credit assignments though which is nice. However, I am a fairly good student and am someone who loves science (I am even a bio major), and I found this class to be a struggle that made me like science a lot less.

Dr. Ngeve is a very nice women and cared about her students' success. However, lectures were really hard to follow. Some of the exam questions were not related to anything we learned. There were a lot of weirdly worded questions on the exams that tripped students up to the point where she just gave us back points. She does provide so many extra credit opportunities, which is saving my grade to be honest. She lets us drop one of the midterm grades and the final is open book/note/internet. The homeworks are graded too harshly and I feel like I am rushing through my exams. Overall, she is a very nice woman and cares about us, but this class was difficult for me.
She clearly cares about teaching and will spend time answering any questions you have. Very attentive and a good teacher

She is a really nice professor and you can tell she genuinely cares about her curriculum and her students, but her teaching style was not the best. She did not provide a lot of opportunities in class to practice problems and go over how to do the homework afterward. Her exams are okay (7 or 8 free responses + 35 multiple choice questions per exam). It isn't too bad if you studied and know the material, but if you don't, it's an uphill battle for sure. I don't typically struggle with school, but this class was very challenging for what seemed like no reason. Also, she goes very fast in person so having the slides up while in class is helpful and/or going back and watching her pre-recorded lectures helps a lot. Overall, she's okay. I've had better and I've had worse.
TERRIBLE PROFESSOR. do not take. exams are extremely unfair. 0/5 rating.

Good fucking lord. 
I thought I had my fair share of bad teachers in high school and MAN was I wrong. I attended two lectures of this class ever because there is literally NO POINT in attending lecture. Her ENTIRE lecture is just her reading off a powerpoint slide WORD FOR WORD with incoherent rambling mixed in. Half the time she won't tell you ways to remember them but rather go on some completely unrelated and irrelevant tangent. If you ever wonder why communications is a gen ed requirement, the average Reaka lecture is your answer. You can get a rock fuckin solid 10 hours of sleep the night before one of her lectures and you will still nod off. Shit, she should stop being a professor and be an anethesiologist so she be paid for putting people to sleep on purpose. Shit dude, I am more invested in writing this dumbass fucking review than I was in this class for the entirety of the semester. You will gain nothing from her lectures. You don't even have to be there for the first lecture because they. are. all. the. same.

So ok, she reads her powerpoints out loud. So what? Well, here's the kicker. In my last year of high school, I downloaded some of my textbooks because covid and whatnot. HER SLIDES FOR ONE TOPIC ARE BIGGER THAN A FUCKING TEXTBOOK. Now, to be fair, images take up more space than text, but look, on average, this shit is roughly 60 to 70 slides long. It takes multiple lectures to get through one topic. The individual slides look like shitposts for a biology meme group and are crammed with the skimmings of a wikipedia article. As for her tests, she will usually release a "study guide" a few days before the test. Your best bet is to study from the slides or the study guide by writing copious notes on whatever is mentioned. It's not just that she is a horrible lecturer, she can't be bothered to make the material remotely learnable. Heck, I don't think she even tries to cut out shit that's not relevant. 

So overall, you may notice other reviews that say you have to work hard to earn an A in this class. If you do things right and be very smart about what you study, it's almost like an async class. But I'll be honest, it's not worth your time. You will walk away from this class with less than you started, because you will have spent your sanity studying whether or not a certain species of bacteria grows a second anus before or after it grows a mouth because she mentioned it in half a sentence on her slide on a whim.

Dogshit "professor" and I hope I never take a class with her again. Don't take this class, enjoy college.

Leo reads nearly word for word off of the slide. Although slides are posted after class, you've lost the chance to take notes on what he is actually saying since you have to scribble down whatever the slide said to make your notes somewhat relevant. Exam Pts were taken off for the smallest of mistakes. I had to self-teach myself most of this class. HW (LearningCurves) are very tedious. I don't recommend Leo at all.
Do not recommend. Her lecture is pretty boring. The final exam weights too much. She drops 1 midterm. Her exams are short but hard and detailed.

This is class EXTREMELY BORING. Like all the other reviews have said, she literally reads from the slides word for word. There is absolutely no attempt in order to keep students engaged in the activity. So I wouldn't recommend students, especially people new to biology to take this class. However, if there aren't any other teachers available, here are some major tips to help you succeed. 
1. There is a LOT of information in this course, so make sure you stay organized and understand the general ideas of the topics.
2. She points out a lot of examples in class that are also on the PowerPoint slides. These are vital pieces of information, as she very often cherrypicks one of those examples and puts them on a test.
3. Exams require a lot of understanding and critical thinking. Many questions are full of words that you have to be able to decipher like a secret code. Don't overthink the questions.
This class requires time and effort in order to earn an A, but it isn't hard to pass since the weight of tests is smaller in comparison to other classes. Best of luck to future students.
-

IGNORE the reviews take Reaka. Class is so easy and she's nice and willing to help. Barely studied and got an A. Used lectures to de-stress and look at cool animal pictures. Have to say her graphic design skills need some work. Yellow on a blue gradient background is not the move but this class was a fun time.

Though the teacher is extremely nice and understanding, there are about 100 other people in the class who may have similar or more significant problems than yourself in this class and if you do not have a decent foundation in biology before taking this class, you will lose track and could fall behind very quickly. Would not recommend taking it as an elective or introductory 100 class.

She is so nice. It can be hard to understand her sometimes in class, but she really cares about making sure she's always there to help her students out. She does questions in class which help prepare for all the exams so write or take a pic of them, she responds right away to all emails. There are 3 reg exams and then an additional one for the final (cumulative). I would say right from the start do ALL the extra credit it boosts your grade by so much and she drops one exam score. I know her exams cover a lot more than other teachers so if you want to study less then pick another professor cus she treats this like a 200 level bio class.

Dr. Bruns is very passionate about the content in this course and it really shows during her lectures. She truly cares that her students are learning something. As for the course itself, the exams are very fair if you follow what she puts out in the study guide, and you can also bring in a notecard during exams. Your lowest midterm also gets dropped which is a nice perk. Overall, she makes the class enjoyable to attend, and makes the workload manageable, for this course I would take this professor if you can!

She is smart but holy cow she cannot teach.  She will show a practice problem and read it off the screen, and instead of showing how to do it, she will just say, "ok so do the practice problem by finding the answer.  Now I hope that was good and you understand".  No, prof Ngeve, I did not understand bc you didn't say how to do it!!!  Everything in her class has to be self-taught because lord knows she doesn't know how to do it, but you don't have time to stay on top of it and teach yourself an entire biology course.  The concepts aren't too hard, they are just boring and weird, so even if you did have the time, you aren't gonna wanna sit down and learn it.   I really wish I could say more nice things about her class because she is actually a nice person, but you will be completely on your own with learning this material.

She is a really kind person, but there is so much material to keep up with that it often requires a lot of last-minute self-teaching studying, especially before exams. She does drop the lowest exam, and for this semester at least she is allowing the final exam to be open book and open internet which is really helpful grade wise. She offers a lot of extra credit opportunities, and a lot of the assignments do balance out the exams so its not totally overpowering.

She truly cares about her students and if you spend the time to ask her a question after class she is very thorough. In the beginning of the year I think she moved very quickly through her lecture slides and it was hard to follow, however after receiving this feedback she began to slow down mid-semester and this was helpful. The extra credit is a necessity, it is amazing. I would recommend her to other students!

I actually really like Professor Ngeve. At first, because of the workload and the 8-10 page assignments, I was put-off by her but after going to her office hours just one time, I foudn that she is so kind and really wants us all to succeed in her class. The workload in this class is very heafty and could bring down your grade if you do not do well but she provides so much extra credit just in case that happens. However, the lectures do have a LOT and i mean, A LOT of material. You learn it on day and are expected to come back with all the knowledge in your brain. Its a bit insane but if you stay EXTREMELY on top of it, you will be just fine. The notes on the lectures were a bit hard for me to follow so it is important that you understand the material.

Prof Ngeve is a nice person but she is not a great teacher. She is lenient with late homework if you contact her! The lectures are not engaging and although it is sometimes helpful to have her further explain the content on the slides, most of the time she just reads off of the slides. It is hard to retain any information because the lectures are boring. I did not do well on any of the homeworks given in this class and the feedback is just irrelevant by the time they give it back usually.

I would recommend Dr. Ngeve to anyone planning on taking BSCI160. I will admit that ecology is not my strongsuit, but Dr. Ngeve provides plentiful resources for anyone to succeed. She posts her powerpoint slides, recorded lectures, and other resources to help with difficult material. It is impossible not to learn with the abundance of resources and support she provides. It is clear that she knows the material thoroughly and is passionate about sharing it with her students. She has high expectations for her students, but I think it is fair given how much she does to make sure that we understand the material. There are also tons of extra credit opportunities to boost your grade.
W fr

She is extremely knowledgable. She moves very fast paced which takes a little bit of getting used to, but she is very helpful when trying to understand a topic. The questions she uses as practice in class are directly related to the key concepts and takeaways of each chapter. Each of her lectures are recorded which makes it easy to review or take notes prior to class. Professor Ngeve also encourages questions and tries her best to answer these questions to make sure the student completely understands the information they are asking about. There is a lot of studying that needs to be done outside of class as most of the content is memorization.

Not a great professor, but a very nice person. She doesn't explain concepts well in class, so a lot of it has to be taught by yourself at home. The homework and extra credit are really nice, though, because they brought my grade up a lot.

Professor Ngeve is very understanding and a nice person. She wants everyone in her class to do well and gives you more than enough resources you need to succeed in her class. You have to do a lot on your own though, and the work sometimes is tedious, but rewarding if you really understand her teaching. You have to know your notes from class, and my advice is to take your notes on paper and pencil off your computer while you are in class, because she usually does not finish the slides in class and you are still expected to know it. However, everything is always posted so it is not hard to access anything that you need in her class. I would recommend taking her class because she wants you to learn and succeed, and your grade is not just based on your exam scores.

Dr. Ngeve is definitely a good teacher. She does push you and give you an ample amount of work, but it is reasonable. The teaching style is fast in order to cover topics but she does try and spend and explain as much on it as she can. She is a fair grader and offers a lot of helpful extra credit which I would recommend starting from the beginning and not just doing it when you need. Her tests are fair and she is a great teacher.

She definitely cares about students' learning and encourages the class to ask questions during lecture. The homework assignments were time consuming but definitely helped with digesting the content. All the lectures are recorded and posted which is really nice. The weekly discussion assignment usually relates to exam content and is helpful to study. I found the exams to be difficult; the content was not unfamiliar, I just felt very rushed especially on any math-related questions. I recommend doing any extra credit assignments - there are a decent amount which can really help your grade.

Dr. Ngeve is very caring and always encourages students to ask questions in class. I recommend attending ULA review session if you take this class to perform well. Lecture content can be hard and confusing, but if you take a little bit of extra time to practice the material, it will be worthwhile. Dr. Negeve's exams are also fair game and I never felt like I received a question that was not covered in either lecture or a review session.

Dr. Ngeve is a very good teacher; she truly wants everyone of her students to succeed. She offers an insane amount of extra credit assignments that not only help you learn the material but really boost your grade. Furthermore, the exams often are based directly off of content reviewed in class (particularly clicker questions). The Homework assignments can be a bit challenging (and I think potentially going over them more in class could be really useful). She also allows students to use a notecard with information, which makes the overwhelming amount of content alot more barable.

She is a really nice professor! She really cares about us and only wants us to exceed. She's always available for help and to answer any questions. The only thing is the grading is a little harsh, especially on the homework assignments. There are also no curves but she does drop your lowest test score.

Dr. Ngeve is a very nice person and definitely knows her stuff, however, her class can be a bit difficult. She does weekly discussion posts, which are very helpful with review. She also does clicker questions in class so those are a good review as well as easy points, especially since those questions show up on the exam. What frustrated me about her class was the homework since they were graded pretty harshly. On gradescope, it doesn’t really tell you what you did wrong and there were times where it felt like points were u justly taken off. Dr. Ngeve does give tons of extra credit for you to work on so there is definitely ways to boost your grade in this class. All in all, the class was ok

She's really nice and wants you to get to the content and questions right. I appreciate that she took our feedback about exams and shortened them after a lot of us had to rush to finish the first exams. Sometimes there's a lot of information on the slides so in class it's better to focus on the information she adds on and not writing down every word on the slide. In class, she puts up point solutions questions -- make sure to take notes on those because they tend to show up on the multiple choice section of exams. She offers a lot of extra credit opportunities, which is great, but some have to be completed in a random group who can be hard to work or connect with but there's A LOT of chance for extra credit and they're really not that difficult to do so try to do as much of the extra credit assignments as possible. She also drops an exam which is really helpful and you can bring a notecard with notes to the midterm. If you have any questions about homework or the material I would recommend going straight to her office hours instead of the TAs because sometimes the TA's answers were kind of confusing because they're trying not to tell you the answer. For exams, long as you give yourself enough time to consistently review (maybe like a week) before midterms and look over all the point solutions, you should be good.

Dr. Ngeve is a great teacher! She honestly truly cares for her students and wants everyone to succeed. She's very responsive through emails and was able to help me whenever I was confused about a topic! I would say though, her homeworks are a bit challenging. Other than that, her class was fairly easy!

she really cares about her students and is very patient, and wants us to succeed. the course is definitely very content heavy, which she explicitly stated on the very first day, so she treats this class more like a 200 level class. the exams are pretty lengthy but a lot of the questions come straight from point solutions we did in class, so they're definitely doable, and the lowest out of the three midterms are dropped. there's also A LOT of extra credit that boosts your grade significantly and relates to topics we learned so it's great review. the weekly discussion posts are also a great review of what we learned that week so. overall, the class is very content heavy but dr. ngeve does a great job making sure she gives out all the resources we need to succeed and is very understanding and patient.

This professor truly cares about her students. She posts all of the powerpoints and records her lectures which is very helpful. She posts lots of resources that help you prepare for midterms and makes the practice midterm much harder than the actual midterm, so you're always prepared. If you pay attention, there's never a surprise on the midterms. There is a reasonable amount of work and A LOT of extra credit opportunites to keep your grade high.
She really cares about her student's learning and offers lots of extra credit!

Dr. Ngeve truly care about students, she goes well and beyond to help anyone who needs it. She is super encoring and so easy to work with. I really appreciate the time she take to answer any question or address any concerns we have. Her recorded lecture were truly a huge help especially since there's a lot of information to be learned so it's always nice to go back to it and review it for the test. I do have to emphasize that this course have A LOT of information (there's a fair amount of work and efforts needed to be put in) but she gives everything you need to succeed in this class. I recommend doing ALL the extra credit work she provided, it's definitely a boost to your grades. Generally, super helpful professor, definitely one of the best.

She rocked... Whenever there was a problem or concern she would always work with you to resolve it. She also made it an ongoing effort of hers to answer any question or explain any material that is confusing to you.
Great instructor, cares about students. Explains material well, offers extra credit and is all around helpful in your success.

Great professor, extremely interesting class! I loved the course and how the material was taught as well as the order it was taught in. This class requires you to connect big concepts together and can be a lot, but it is extremely rewarding. There is quite a bit of work involved and you have to make sure you recognize the point at which you need help, and in the weekly discussion, you can post your questions for that week and the professor will respond answering them all! Although grading is a bit harsh, the lowest test is dropped and there are also many extra credit assignments you can do.

Dr. Ngeve cares a lot for a students and does her best to encourage her students to get involved in the topics. This course is very content-heavy so, it requires more time to understand the concepts that are being taught. Her lectures are packed with information but, if you miss anything she's more than happy to help in office hours and she has recordings from previous semesters. She does provide a lot of extra credit opportunities which is great. She does weekly discussion posts called "Thursday Night Redigest" and homework assignments occasionally. One thing to note about these homework assignments are that they are very harshly graded so, I'd recommend reaching out to either her or the TAs for help. In terms of exams, her MCQs model after her in-class "clicker" questions so, attending class will help. She drops the lowest exam grade and her final is cumulative and open-notes. Personally, I thought this was an okay class and it does require more work but with time, it is doable.
Lots of extra credit assignments and points to boost your grade. If you want to succeed in this class, there are many ways for them to help you.

Dr. Ngeve is actually the best BSCI160 this school might have. And I don't say that lightly. 

I'm usually very unbiased with who I deem an excellent professor, and I can happily assure you that she is the teacher to register with. As someone who was an active participant and made sure to ask questions, Dr. Ngeve was always there to make sure that I understood the material and to continue to challenge me to consider other factors that may play into the content. She is truly a professor who cares for the students. 

Her exams are fair based on material given in lecture slides, study them and you will do fine. Sometimes her free responses are OD long though so watch out for that, you should still be fine. 
She gives out so much extra credit, that it would be a shame for you not to do some throughout your time with her. 
Her homework is long but she gives you more than enough time to complete it (weeks). 
Her redigests are actually useful and help you understand the material. 
She engages with you in class and does care about your success, but she does expect you to try your best and seek the help you need. 

Stan Dr. Ngeve.

Dr. Ngeve is an extremely well rounded professor who answers emails in less than an hour, always assist on discussion posts and will always help no matter the topic. Her exams do cover a lot of material which the only downside, sometimes it is extremely overwhelming with the amount of material you have to know. There are over 40 points of extra credit and each exam you are allowed one notecard. The final is open note as well. Her main goal is for the class to succeed as a whole.

You can tell that she is caring and wants you to succeed as a student. Always available to help you if you need it. Her lectures are a bit fast paced but as the semester goes on you get used to it. She offers several extra credit opportunities throughout the semester that really help boost your grade and also help you gain extra knowledge on the material learned in class. The homework is a lot of work but they are spread out throughout the semester and there is plenty of time to complete them.

Dr. Ngeve is a great professor. She truly cares about how well her students are learning the content and tries to accommodate everyone as best she can. After each exam, she genuinely listens to the feedback that students give her and tries to implement them into her future lectures/exams. All of the assignments reflect the course content and she provides all the materials on Elms (class lectures and panapto recordings). She also gives a lot of extra credit opportunities and assignments that buffer grades.

Dr. Ngeve is truly an amazing person and a good lecturer. She cares about her students!!! She is very quick to answer questions via email, wants every student to succeed, and offers so many extra credit opportunities (SO many). Please take this professor. She makes it clear that to do well in her class you must put in the work and your grade will reflect the amount of work you put in, but this is a given for almost every science/STEM course you will take here at UMD. I did not do as well as I'd hoped on the first exam (C+) and still have an A+ in the class because of the opportunities she gives to bring up your grade. I cannot stress enough how good of a professor she is. Work hard and it will be worth it. The only rough part of this class are the homework assignments but try your best and you'll be fine.

I love this professor and I loved his class. I would 100% recommend him to everyone for BSCI 160. He is very straightforward with his assignments and due dates. He is extremely enthusiastic and intelligent in his lectures although some of them might be long winded. Some people say his lectures are boring, but I disagree I think it is what you make it. I would advise sitting closer to him in the lecture as its easier to stay engaged, and don’t hesitate to participate as it makes it more interesting! He is easily one of my favorite professors of all time.

she really is a kind teacher and definitely wants her students to succeed. she gives a lot of extra credit which is great for your grade and even has point solution questions too which are basically the multiple choice on exams. would definitely recommend!

Dr. Ngeve is a very thoughtful professor who truly cares about her students. She listens to feedback from students and her exams are fairly straightforward. You are also allowed a notecard on the exam which is really helpful. She gives a lot of extra credit which is really nice.

Overall good class, Dr. Ngeve definitely wants you to succeed and offers you numerous opportunities to do so by providing lots of extra credit chances and practice questions during class which significantly help you in preparing for the exam. Sometimes she goes fast during lectures because there is a lot of material to cover. Luckily, she posts recordings of all the lectures and the PowerPoints as well, which are both helpful. Would recommend for sure!

Great teacher, really cares about her students learning the material and encourages students to ask any questions they have during class to make sure they understand the content. There are a lot of opportunities for extra credit in this class and the assignments aren't too hard, so it's not super difficult to get a good grade in the class if you pay attention and stay up to date with the material. The time limit for the tests is the only part I can see being difficult for people, but if you understand and can apply the material, it's not too difficult. In addition, she posted her slides on Canvas along with recorded lectures in case you missed class or didn't understand something. Overall, very nice woman and good teacher.

She really wants every student to d well and provides a lot of easy points (Thursday Night Redigests, Extra Credit Assignments, Point Solutions). Its a content heavy class so she goes a little fast, but as long as you're on top of the lecture, you should be good. Also the things she really wants you to know she'll repeat a bunch.

I loved taking this course! It is very easy to follow the material for each unit throughout the course. As long as you pay attention in lecture and review the lecture slides to make sure you understand the topics, you will be fine. Dr. Ngeve very clearly cares about the success of her students and puts in the effort to give you all the materials you need to succeed. She posts the slides for each lecture, as well as a recording of her presenting the slides in a little more detail, and they're both very helpful in their own ways. I would always use them to take my notes outside of lecture so I could go at my own pace, and I could always go back to any single lecture throughout the semester. The assignments are all designed to make sure you understand what you are learning, and there's plenty of extra credit opportunities. I definitely recommend taking this course with Dr. Ngeve, you'll be set!!

Dr. Ngeve is the kindest professor I have met at UMD. She made our classroom experience so welcoming, and always encouraged and validated questions. Our lectures were mostly done via powerpoint, with participation questions (about 3-5) every class to review the information. I have seen some students mention her pacing as an issue, so if you struggle with writing and listening at the same time, you may benefit from taking notes on her lectures beforehand (the entire course is on ELMS from the first day, and every lecture has a powerpoint and recording, depending on what learning style you have). The thing I love most about Dr. Ngeve is that she gives her students as many opportunities as possible to take charge of their learning and improve their grades. She offers a lot of extra credit throughout the semester, usually in the form of learning activities and self-awareness reflections. While the class itself does not have a curve (aside from EC), my friends and I who regularly did extra credit often had over a 100% in the class. The exams can be challenging, but they often reuse participation and practice exam questions. Additionally, students are allowed a notecard in every midterm exam, and our final this year is open internet. A lot of doing well in this class is based upon demonstrated effort. Even if you do not do well on exams or homework (I have never gotten an A on any exams, and I usually don't get all of my homework assignments correct), it is still possible to do very well (I literally have over a 99 despite the stuff I mentioned earlier). If you spend time studying, pay attention in class, and do extra credit, this course will be well worth your time and very helpful to your GPA. Not to mention that, again, Dr. Ngeve is clearly passionate about what she does and cares about all of her students much more than I have seen any other professor do so. If you are taking 160, please consider Ngeve!

She was a really good teacher. I like how the class was recorded but you did need to go for point source solution answers (participation points). She tried really hard to explain things and she did well. Just know that she does have an accent so you need to really pay attention when she is talking. Over all enjoyed this class though.
Very fair and seems to genuinely care about the content and grades of her students. Lectures can be a little fast paced and kind of crunched for time especially at the end of each class.

The class is honestly a lot of work, and you will probably have to spend a good amount studying for this course. However, you can tell that Dr.Ngeve really cares about her students. There are lot of assignments and extra credit that are great for boosting your grade outside of the exams.
She's a wonderful professor and teacher.  None of the assignments were busy work.  They all helped you understand the topics taught.  The midterms were fair.  The final is open internet.

This teacher is very nice, cares about her students and provides a lot of extra credit work and exams are not hard at all. Only thing I would say is the homework are a bit tricky, but overall would recommend because she makes it hard not to pass the class. Just go to class and actually study for exams and you will do really well.
She deeply cares about students' success and provides lots of extra credit opportunities. Heavy material , though. So you have to make sure you truly study in this course
Great instructor, cares about students. Explains material well, offers extra credit!!
She is nice and passionate about what she teaches, but the lecture is very fast paced and homework assignments are rather difficult and harshly graded
Very nice, has lots of extra credit oppurtunities, and the final exam is slight.

She's a good professor and gives lots of opportunities for extra credit and optional learning activities. If you're willing to do the work to get that extra credit it will give you buffer for exams because the exams are long and hard. Also willing to give students extensions if your sick or something she's cooperative.
Professor Ngeve is a good professor but sometimes her slides were out of order. Her tests were a bit difficult but the Point Solution Questions were helpful in reviewing content.
She is a great professor and posts her recorded lectures which can be very helpful in preparing for exams!
The lectures were hard to follow and the homework grading was extreme but the extra credit was helpful

shes a very nice professor and seems like she genuinely cares about the content and student, but i feel like she doesnt go very much in-depth with the topics. I do like the extra credit she provide you!

Fair teacher and provides a lot of opportunity for extra credits. However there is a LOT of content covered (for BSCI160) and if you are not on top of everything you may fall behind. The class is not difficult, but I struggled because I personally had trouble acclimating to the college course load. Even so I still am doing well in the class because there are a lot of resources available (lectures online, review sessions, etc).

I think Dr. Ngeve is a really great professor! She is very caring and you can tell she does her best to ensure success for her students. For example, she'll encourage us to ask questions and provides lots of extra credit. However, her lectures are pretty fast-paced but they are recorded. As long as you're taking proper notes and give yourself enough time to study for her exams you'll be good.

Extremely nice teacher! She has a great class and gave the students TONS of opportunities to make points back via extra credit and exam grading for free response questions. I did feel that lectures were slightly rushed and often had a lot of information crammed in. She is very approachable though and I enjoyed this class.

An extraordinarily fair professor and clearly displayed that she wanted everyone to succeed. The only thing I would recommend is explain topics better and use more relatable examples. As a student in this course I struggled with retaining information, additionally she could work on providing more example in class, as we would often go over one concept, and say "I hope you understand this idea now", although we spent a few minutes on the concept and were often still confused or felt uneasy about it.

I really liked her, I thought she was a kind person and very much wanted her students to succeed. She always encouraged us to ask questions and consistently had opportunities for learning outside of class. We had an assignment every week in the material learned from last week and I think this was helpful to remind me of the information learned in lecture and solidify it in my brain. She also offered a lot of extra credit opportunities which were helpful in expanding learning, she had individual and group EC to help address the styles of learning of a wide group of people. The clicker questions in class were also helpful to my learning. The exams were very fast paced and a lot content but I think if you prepare enough a head of time it is possible to do very well. The only thing I disliked was that sometimes we didn't finish material in lecture and she would move on to the next lecture the next class instead of finishing the old lecture. I would have been fine with this cause I know she has to cover a certain amount of material, but I would have liked better if she reminded us that the previous lecture was unfinished and that we need to review that on our own. I often forgot and it got stressful toward the exam when I realized I was missing chunks of knowledge I needed to know. She does drop one of the exams which helps with the stressfulness of taking the exams and our final is open book which relieves some pressure cause it is cumulative. Overall I would say she Is a good teacher and kind person.
She was a good professor who cared about teaching and having students learn. She provided a lot of ways for extra credit to boost your grade, however, the exams weren't a walk in the park.

Dr. Ngeve is an extremely nice and understanding professor. She is very accommodating and will almost always give an extension or help you reschedule an exam if needed. With that being said, her class is not that easy. Her lectures are very fast paced, and sometimes hard to understand and apply to actual problems. If you want to have a good grade in her class, you will need to do the extra credit and there is quite a bit. The TAs grade the homework's very strictly as well. Her weekly discussion boards can sometimes be very tedious and time consuming, but it is helpful to look at other people's responses. Overall this class is not that easy and will take a lot of your time as you need to work to understand lectures. She does drop her lowest exam grade, which is useful.

Dr. Ngeve really cares about her students and wants everyone to do well on the exams. She encourages students to ask questions in class when anything is confusing. That being said, paying attention in her lectures alongside the discussion and the extra credit helped a lot. The exams are not easy, but there are a lot of resources she provides to be able to study well for the exams.

The HW and exams are graded to the most minute detail; exams especially are ridiculously long for the time allotted and are very difficult. I would advise people to avoid this course and this teacher.

Dr. Ngeve is very nice and shows that she cares. She's always open to any questions you might have. She also offers a lot of extra credit which is extremely helpful. The lectures can be hard to follow at times and the homeworks are very hard as well as the exams. Definitely do the extra credit work.
Great professor, explained the materials very well., and post extra practice for extra credit. She is amazing.

Professor Ngeve is very flexible with extensions and rescheduling exams, however, this class is A LOT of work. If you have a heavier course load or have other classes that require more attention - like me, then this class could be very hard to pass. Other than that, there are many extra credit opportunities (make sure to do all of them and that will give you a pretty good grade boost), and make sure to do well on the homework. There are three midterm exams and one final that is open book/open note/ open internet which takes some of the pressure off the last exam. Overall, this course really is what you make of it and it's important to do well because there is no curve. Professor Ngeve cares a lot about her students and gives them the tools to succeed, however, you really need to be on top of the work in this class otherwise you will fall behind!

Even though I'm expecting a B in this class, I absolutely LOVED it. He is extremely passionate about the subject. I have to admit, it's pretty boring at times. However, the TA's do great with exam prep and if you do bad on the tests it's honestly your fault at that point. Literally the only studying I do is going to the zoom calls and making a few flashcards on quizlet. Also matches up pretty well with ENSP101 (not related but I think will help some people)
nice professor!! fast paced lectures and the weekly "thursday night redigest" are time consuming.  extra credit assignments are worth it.

Solid Professor, gives tons of extra credit which helps grades. However, she goes pretty fast-paced but it's a dense course so that is understandable. She cares a lot about her students and is a great professor!

Dr. Ngeve is more than wonderful. ist clear that she wants everyone in her class to succeed. you would be lucky to have her. though she wants to see you succeed, you need to put the work in, but she gives you more than enough resources to succeed.
She was a very kind and understanding professor, but she has many tedious assignments and grades the HW harshly.

Dr. Ngeve is a great professor. She is very accommodating and cares for her students.  While she may go a little fast during lecture, she does post lecture videos which are very helpful. She also posts slideshows and other useful resources related to the unit that she is teaching. She does give extra credit. Also the homework is taken very seriously, so make sure to do good on them as they are graded strictly. The exams are not the easiest, however, if you pay attention in class and look back at notes, you should be okay.

Dr. Ngeve was a great professor. Taking her class in my first semester of college was a very big blessing. The content can be a lot, but that is to be expected of this type of biology course. What sets Dr. Ngeve apart from other professors is how understanding she is. Her canvas page is very well organized with annotated powerpoints and video recordings that make reviewing content easy to access and understand. The exams are hard, but you should be successful if you study the clicker questions and review content. She offers plenty of extra credit opportunities to help you lift your grade up after exams and she is very helpful with any questions. She gives you many opportunities to have success in the course. I fully recommend her.

She is an amazing professor who really wants to see her students succeed. During class, she stops to make sure that people get a chance to ask questions (although she can be a little rude if she finds the question to be too easy). She also gives point solution questions throughout the lecture to make sure we understand the content as we go. A LOT of these questions show up the exact same way on the exams so make sure you study them! She makes sure to be available for questions which I like. Also, we recently found out that the final would be open note, open internet which is really nice. Finally, there are a lot of opportunities for extra credit and if you do them all they will help your grade A LOT. Overall, a really good professor. My main complaint would be that the slides are a little disorganized so they can be kind of hard to follow but she records and posts the lectures on ELMS which helps with review or if you miss class.

Dr. Ngeve is a kind professor. She pre-records her lectures so when it comes to having to study fro exams it is very helpful. The exams are not as hard as some other classes as long as you know the material as well as study the point solution questions. She may mix up the point solution questions a little bit but as long as you know the question and the answer you will be able to get the exam questions. She also gives multiple opportunities to get extra credit, which helped my grade. She can move a little fast but that is what the given powerpoints and lecture videos are for.

Greta professor, always open to help as best she can. A lot of extra credit opportunities and homework assignments are great way to practice material learned in class. Some TA's are harsh graders so it helps to compare answers with peers. Her lectures are not too fast-paced but there is a lot of information that has to be covered so the pace might feel too fast for some. There are available recorded lectures and lecture slides online though so you shouldn't worry about missing anything. Exams are well made. They test on information that was actually covered and some questions are even ones that we have done on assignments or in class. You will be fine if you attend class, pay attention and do the assignments.

I really liked Dr. Ngeve. She always made me feel comfortable to reach out regarding extra help. Her office hours were helpful and she is very understanding. Her lectures were fast paced but she posted recordings for each lecture that were helpful to rewatch.

She has really good intentions for the course, but it ended up being more tedious than anything else. One of the best aspects of the course was the TNR which helped you understand the topics as they were taught. The worst aspects were the lectures. She goes into a lot of detail for each lecture which makes it hard to understand what is actually important. I found myself understanding the topics more if I just went over the slides and skimmed through her pre-recorded videos. The canvas page can also be overwhelming since there is so much information on it.

Dr. Ngeve is a great professor. Some concepts of BSCI160 can be hard to grasp at first but she explains it well. I cannot stress this enough, you need to raise your hand if you have a question or don't understand the concepts, or she won't know. She is always happy to answer questions, reexplain a concept, or slow down if someone tells her, because she genuinely cares about her students and their learning. This goes for any professor in general; you need to be proactive. Presentations and the recordings of them are posted before lecture if you need them. She gives lots of extra credit opportunities; some of them are group activities (learning activities) which I wasn't the biggest fan of since we didn't choose our groups, but if you have responsive groupmates, it makes completion a lot more bearable. For an information-heavy class, the exams are very fair, are similar to the questions she gives in class on point solution(participating in these also gives extra credit points, they're not graded by accuracy), and she allows one notecard to bring for each midterm. Overall, I highly recommend her for BSCI160.

Dr. Ngeve is a wonderful professor that shows great passion in her work and within her presentations. Even while sick, when most professors would simply cancel class, Dr. Ngeve held zoom lectures and provided time to her students to help with their assignments. She provides help to her students to an extent that I have not seen from other professors. Her presentations are well structured, but can move at a faster pace at times. Once you are comfortable with the speed of the lectures, have a way of following the presentation with the Point Solution, and get comfortable with her accent, her class will become one of your favorites. Dr. Ngeve provides many extra credit assignments that run parallel with her content. I would completely recommend Dr. Ngeve to up coming students and thus is why I'm giving her five stars.
A very nice professor who cares about you and you're learning. Lectures are very dense and homework is graded very harshly but EC opportunities are available.

She is a charming professor! However, there is so much content placed into each exam. During the lecture, we got through about 40 slides, which were all content-heavy. The content can be tough to follow since she zooms through it and only gives you a little time to comprehend what's happening. In addition, TAs grade homework and sometimes tend to take off unnecessary points. This class can be challenging and time-consuming for a first-year student taking other stem-heavy classes like chemistry.

This course just did not strike me the right way. I took 170 first and really enjoyed that course. I generally just did not enjoy the material for 160. That being said, I did not have many interactions with Dr. Ngeve outside of class. I stopped attending lecture about half-way through the semester because I couldn't learn in class and instead watched the recorded lectures. I found her comments in class to be antagonistic and she got visibly frustrated when people were not participating in class. I might have had a better opinion of her if I attended her office hours, but I did most of my learning in this class via recorded lectures instead.

Dr. Ngeve is a very understanding and hardworking professor. A lot of content is covered in her lectures, her exams are pretty difficult due to the number of questions you need to complete in a certain period of time, and you need to devote a lot of time to her class. However, there are many opportunities to bring up your grade, such as extra credit assignments and her weekly discussion posts. Additionally, she drops the lowest grade out of your three midterms.

She's super nice. Her pacing is a little bit too fast for my liking but to each their own. Her homeworks and TNRs are sometimes pretty lengthy and difficult. Her exams aren't the easiest either. But we're allowed a notecard for exams and she gives a lot of extra credit assignments, which is the reason why I have a decent grade.

Dr. Ngeve is a very thoughtful and thorough professor who gives great details about the subject matter. It is very apparent that she really cares about her students and their learning. She offers a lot of extra credit and as long as you stay on top of learning, you should do well in the class. The class is NOT curved though, so you really need to work hard to earn your grade. Exams are also no walk in the park so keep that in mind. Do be warned that she goes pretty fast, but it is necessary to get through all of the material. Overall, I would definitely recommend her!

Professor Ngeve is very fair and she cares about her students. She is a great lecturer, however, if you're the type of person that needs to see information on slides, don't take her. The lecture powerpoints are not very helpful at all, as there are many slides with just pictures on them or the smallest amount of bullet points. The exams are kind of hard but she drops the lowest one, which is nice. The TA's grade the homework really harsh, which can bring down your homework average, but the extra credit is really helpful.

Pros:
Lots of(I mean, seriously, lots of) extra credits if you have enough time to do those extra credit assignments
Review session every week is helpful
Drop lowest exam
Final is open book, open internet, open everything(though I don't know if it is an advantage yet since I haven't take the final yet)
Cons:
Lecture is boring and not attracting
There is in-class participation points, which basically mean if you don't want to lose those precious points, you need to take every single lecture and respond to her questions on your device which is very annoying to me.
Exams are pretty hard

Afterall, I think the extra credit provided is enough to compensate for those cons, but the "in-class participation points" really irritates me, otherwise I would give her 4/5 or even 5/5. It's college, not high-school. Professors should not force the students to come to every lecture using this kind of method, instead, teaching interesting lecture will automatically attract students to come, since we all got some business to do, sometimes even emergent, no one can guarantee to show up on every lecture.

I think she did a good job with being an accommodating teacher in order for students to succeed. However, it was hard to understand her at times and the slides are not detailed enough to catch up of you miss something in class. But of you put in the time to do the EC and other activities that boost your grade, you should be fine.

she's such a good lecturer and is extremely intelligent. she is always willing to help and answer questions and is SO accommodating in terms of giving extra credit opportunities and dropping the lowest midterm. the class definitely requires a lot of studying, but dr. ngeve gives you so many resources to help you understand what you're learning. best professor!!!!! love her

Dr.Ngeve is a teacher that cares for the success of her students. She thoroughly explains her lectures, and goes through the content of the class. She provides a lot of resources to help you get a better understanding of the material, and works with her students to ensure they don't fall behind. She also provides a significant amount of extra credit, that will help boost your grade a lot.

Dr.Ngeve was a very engaging professor. While her classes were very fast pace and the homework was graded pretty strictly, her lectures were always engaging and she made sure to answer every question people had, even if that meant doing some research before the next class to give you an answer. While this class is by no means easy, Dr.Ngeve provides lots of resources and opportunities to learn and grasp the content.
She did a good job on lectures but every grade in the class seemed to be graded pretty harshly but there was a lot of opportunities to get extra credit.

Dr. Ngeve really does care about the knowledge her students get out of this course. She offers plenty of extra credit opportunities which expand on what you're learning in class and those are super helpful. The lectures are fast paced and it's easy to fall behind on notes as if we don't get through all of the lecture in class it's up to the student to finish that on their own time. The weekly discussions for homework do take a bit of time as well. This course isn't going to be an easy A and definitely requires you to really put in the work if you want to succeed. But she's there for you every step of the way to help.
