He is an excellent teacher. He genuinely wants you to understand the topics he is teaching, and is always accommodating to questions. His tests are usually 105 points but he grades them out of 100, so we get those 5 points back, and on top of that each exam is curved generously. He really wants you to excel in his class, and it shows in his teaching.
He is such an amazing teacher. Curves on the tests are great, and he encourages questions. Show up to class it makes a difference!

There are a lot of extra credit opportunities, so use them to your advantage! She's very accommodating and kind. However, the lectures are quite fast-paced, and you will have to digest a lot of information in little time. Make sure to also do your homework early as possible as well, you will need to dedicate quite a lot of time to them.

Dr. Ngeve is a very understanding and kind prof. She genuinely wants everyone to succeed. The tests are very fair but the homework is kinda hard. She is very forgiving though, and homework doesn't count that much.

Dr. Ngeve is an incredibly caring and understanding professor. She always encourages students to ask questions, gives a LOT (I mean a LOT) of extra credit opportunities, and is always accommodating. There is a lot of content covered in this course, but the ULA review sessions hosted by her ULA review team are very useful. In this course, you should review your notes throughout the semester and be sure to ask questions whenever you have them. The homework for this course can be difficult and the exams can be difficult, but there is so much extra credit to cushion these grades - and the lowest of the three midterms was dropped. She keeps her lectures engaging with Point Solution questions that help you review content as you go along, and even has recorded lectures ready if you miss a class or want to review. Participation in this class is also graded through Point Solutions. Dr. Ngeve puts an incredibly amount of effort into ensuring students understand content, and I am so happy to have been in this class and highly recommend it.
Extra credits are helpful, but the homework requires some extra time

I think that Dr. Ngeve was a great teacher considering how other teachers were for BSCI160. She is very consistent on what is expected in her class. She gives us in class participation questions which helps us to reinforce our knowledge, so it isn't really easy to skip class without losing those points. She records her lectures which is especially helpful when going back to study for our exams. She gives quite a bit of extra credit which is a great way to help your grade (some of them are individual and others are in a group). In class, she is a good lecturer and often stops to answer questions that people may have about the topic. Sometimes, she asks a question and then waits for a response and no one answers which can be a bit awkward but is not too bad (we just sometimes don't know the answer so the class is just silent). We also have a weekly discussion post which can either be a good thing or an annoying thing. It's not optional but there are some cases where you can also get extra credit this way. The class is big so it gives you the lecture feel but also like a smaller class because of some of the group work we do. I recommend her because she is patient and will do her best to explain something that you are unsure of. She can seem intimidating at first but don't hesitate to go up to her with a question you have because she will help you with it.

I absolutely loved this class. IMO, her lecturing style is a good pace and she will always encourage you to ask questions. SO MUCH extra credit, and to be honest if you get below a A-B you did not put in the necessary work. The concepts can be hard, but this is an intro bio, so it's to be expected. Ngeve is an acquired taste in terms of lecturing, but after a week or two you will learn to love how attentive she is. Practice questions during every lecture and she's so nice in office hours.
She is a good professor who cares about students actually learning and provided lots of extra credit to boost your grade

Dr. Ngeve is a good professor. She provides multiple opportunities for students to earn extra credit and boost their grades. However, her lectures are very fast paced her exams are very challenging. If you miss one lecture, you will fall behind. Her weekly discussions (TNRs) are very long and take lots of time to complete. She also drops the lowest exam grade. Overall, even though this is a challenging class, she tries her best to make it a little bit easier.
Very nice teacher but gives a lot of work.

Professor Ngeve is a sweet professor!  She gives students loads of opportunities for extra credit that ends up helping their grades a lot in the end. Her class is doable however the content and material covered in this course can be overwhelming. If you are not reviewing her course material at least once every week then you'll more than likely fall behind. Also, she takes participation points so you must attend each of her classes because they are added up at the end of the semester. She does make sure to provide extra resources such as review sessions, recorded lectures, and slide notes for students who need extra help or end up falling behind so that is nice of her as well.
Dr. Ngeve is a really good professor who actually cares about her students learning the material and always answers questions if you email her.

Dr. Ngeve provided a ton of extra credit to earn points back and really cared about her students understanding the material. Lectures at times had a lot of material, but she would focus on certain topics more than others that were tested on. The homeworks were very helpful for understanding the material.
She was a very good professor with very high standards of her students while also being understanding of those who missed some topics or details. Very knowledgeable in the course material

There's no way to fail this course with Dr.Ngeve because she provides soooo much support. She is organized and well prepared for the course. She makes her grading options and participation expectations clear. The extra optional learning credits can keep you floating even if you do not do well on tests. I really do recommend her class.
Professor Ngeve is the best professor ever! She gives everyone the materials needed to pass and do well on her homework, assignments, and exams!

Professor Ngeve cares about her students learning. She encourages questions during lecture and will patiently explain a concept until you understand. She used in class polls to ensure that her students are understanding the material as it is discussed in class.
She is a very nice teacher who gives so much extra credit to bump up your grade. The only issue is how strict the TAs are when grading. They will take points for literally the smallest thing.

Dr. Ngeve is a very competent teacher and is very flexible for office hours. She likes feedback in class and after exams and she’s very responsive to them. For our third exam she shortened it due to comments about long test questions. She offers so many extra credit and they’re all based on completion so don’t feel upset if you can’t answer a few throughly. The Ec boosted my grade so much I ended the course with over 100%. One thing i will say is that the TAs who grade are very picky about the homework but try to cross check questions you are confused about. She lets you bring a note card for every test and the final is 100% open note. The only downside of this class is the TNR discussions which are time consuming.

Even though the lectures aren't the most interesting, she is very knowledgable and teaches everything thats on the exam. There are a few long hw assignments that are graded on accuracy but I recommend going to TA office hours because they basically give you the answers. Her exams are very fair and you should be able to do very well by just studying your notes. This class grade is almost entirely dependent on the exam grades(about 70%) but she does drop the lowest.

Dr. Shapiro is a very intelligent and passionate professor, and he clearly loves the content he teaches.  However, the slides are often disorganized, his lectures drag, and he often rambles in circles which confuses the class and often himself as well.  The "textbook" work is essentially a 40 minute quiz on material we do not need to know for the exam, which doesn't help in learning the material.  He tries to post the lecture slides before class so that he can go very quickly, but oftentimes he forgets and you can't follow along.  The slides are difficult to follow without a lecture alongside them, so going back to get the notes is also difficult.  However, the class itself was pretty easy and his exams were fair.  It's a bit of a nuisance class if you have harder courses like chemistry or calculus, so if you can find a better teacher without ruining your schedule, I'd do it.

I’ve truly loved having her as a professor. She offers so many extra credit opportunities, cares so much about her students, and is a very good lecturer. You get out of it what you put into it. Her class will require work but you are very likely to succeed if you utilize the resources she gives you. Her exams are relevant to her slides and clicker questions. Overall, a 5 star professor. Highly recommend.

Great professor - she is very interested in what she teaches and it really shows.
The exams were not bad, and they only had information from her slides and classes on them.
Nothing much else to say - this is a pretty run-of-the-mill class. If you have to take BSCI160, try to do it with Bruns.
Something minor, but the homeworks and worksheets were time-consuming and confusing, but that's the only gripe I had with this class.

If you have already taken ANTH222 and/or BSCI222 before taking this class, like I did, then BSCI160 is a breeze.
Great professor. He makes the class super straight forward.

I thought that overall, he did a good job. He reads off of slides and goes over them pretty fast. Taking pictures as he goes over them is helpful. He also posts the slides after class, so you can review any topics you do not understand later. Also, the TAs are knowledgeable and can help with understanding tricky homework questions and topics. The midterms were not bad, and the final exam included questions similar to previous midterms. He does tend to get passionate about topics he cares about, which can lead to him rambling for quite some time. The Achieve quizzes were easy as well.

Pretty chill class overall. Lectures are posted on classroom, very straightforward exams. 

Homeworks are a bit of a drag, especially if it stacks up with other classes. For Adaptive quizzes, keep in mind that the content on this is minimally helpful in helping you for the exams.

Dr. Shapiro is extremely passionate. His exams are based on his lecture slides. He also bases questions on figures/graphs on his slides. He only explains those graphs during lecture (he doesn’t record) so if you missed lecture, then you may not understand what the graphs/figures mean. There are weekly quizzes and homework worksheets. Homework is graded extremely hard..very difficult to get 100% since they grade for accuracy. Best resources for this class were GSS and TA review sessions. Overall, this class was quite time consuming and a lot of memorization. I enjoyed the content in this class the most out of my other classes.
He is nice and understanding. He curves well, he wants us to learn is overall great. he really just wants you to try your best and we will reward that.
Exams required heavy studying of material and lecture slides were very dense. I stressed more about her class than I did for Orgo 2.

She's nice, but she's incredibly disorganized. It is not worth it to take this class online for the open note exams because the exam questions don't make sense and some of them are on stuff she barely touched on. The homework questions also barely relate to what we learned and she never actually teaches us how to do problems, so it's a lot of looking stuff up and getting stuff wrong. I have had to put in hours of outside work just to re-learn concepts because she is such a bad teacher. I strongly recommend not taking her class, especially if the class is important to your major or if you are someone that likes to be organized.

I really enjoyed having her as a professor. Her lectures were very clear [and recorded] and had clicker questions that were very helpful and are usually similar to some questions you would see on the exam. She also gives good handouts, has 5 questions homeworks due before each class, online GSS practice texts for each unit (that don't affect your grade and are very similar to the exam), and occasional online weekly quizzes. The exams weren't too bad and the averages were around 70% and for one exam she gave an opportunity to earn some points back. Overall not a hard course and from what I've heard about other professors for 160 she seems like the best by far I would definitely recommend taking Dr. Lee.

Do not take this professor, even if it's the only section available. Class is ridiculously boring, the posted slides aren't the same as the ones she shows in class since they're missing some slides or are in the wrong order. The slides are also just walls of text, so it takes a long time to find information. Exams are impossible, some questions were about content that was never talked about in class. Questions take a long time to read and understand, as do the answer choices, so time is a real threat. Multiple-choice questions have options like "two of the above" so even if you understand the topic and pick one of the right choices, the whole question is wrong. The third midterm is 3 days before the final. The only thing this class has going for it is that she allows 2 attempts on quizzes, but the quizzes are just as hard as the exams.

As a professor he was very excited to teach these topics and seemed to be genuinely interested in what he's teaching. He did this research project on a specific kind of bird and every time he mentioned it you could see his eye light up. When I emailed him at the beginning of the semester unsure if I wanted to continue to take the class as the first few weeks is an adjustment to the work load. He was very kind to me and told me that he thinks I should stick with it but ultimately it was up to me. He would show videos about some of the stuff he was lecturing about which made for a good break from just absorbing information and taking notes. The exams were fairly difficult and I got either a low B or a high C on all 3 of them. There is help for the class that I suggest going to if you want to do better in the course than I did, but it is also manageable to do on your own. Some of the homework assignments are genuinely difficult and hard to comprehend what is being asked of you, the other homework assignments were on macmillan where you had to get a certain amount of points from answering questions and those definitely took a lot of time if you were not fully comprehending the topic. The professor is a great guy and enjoys his class, but the course is still decently difficult.

Don't get me wrong, she is hella qualified in this field, but because of this she makes the course much harder than it should be. Lectures are dense and read off of slides (the times where she does stray off the slides is to go in depth about a species that is interesting but useless for us to memorize), exams are so advance, I had a TA tell me how the format of the exams/ questions are ones she sees in her upper level courses. That being said, we are her first time teaching this course so she didn't know how to dumb it down for us. Also, because we were the first ones, we got an entire retake on Exam I (same exam, questions and answers, and you got the average taken between the two as your final score), and a cheat sheet for Exam II. She is so sweet and caring, but I would hesitate to take her unless you are confident in your test taking skills...

Nice person terrible teacher. Stumbles over her words and stutters nonstop. She rambles about things that have no sustenance and relate nothing to what you need to know. Also very boring professor so concentrating is impossible. If you want to do well you have to read each slide as she has hundreds of slides to pull from for each exam making them harder. But as long as you read her slides you should be fine for the exam if you remember what you read from her hundred long slide units that are boring as ever.

Dr. Rankin is one of the most sweetest and kindest professor I have so far. However, I believe that she has this expectation of student that they should already know what she's talking about. I did great on the third exam because I read ALL The chapters in the textbook and attended her lectures thrice. I might have done better if I attended her lectures. So in summary, if you're gonna take her class, be sure to read the textbook and take notes while you're at it AND attend her lectures with full consciousness because her voice is very soft so its very relaxing in a sense (or it makes you sleepy) and I think you'll be good to go.

Class content is interesting, Dr. Rankin is clearly passionate about the subject. However the exams are extremely difficult especially for a 100-level class (averages in the range of 40-60% and no curve)

I'm really surprised at the amount of low reviews for the other class. I can't really gage how accurate they are, but for BSCI160 she's been a wonderful professor. She's really nice and understanding. She gives very good handouts, and her exams are fair. The exam averages were either high 70s to mid-80s, and the lowest exam score is dropped entirely. I've heard from friends that other BSCI160 professors have 40%~60% for their exam averages. I think she's intent on making students understand rather than just memorize the material. She also does a lot of gestures like bring mandarins or donuts after each test! Overall it's a pretty nice course. I wouldn't call it 'easy', but unlike per se CHEM131, it's more about memorization and conceptual understanding rather than applying knowledge. 120% recommend!

Very sweet lady, but not a fan of the class. Offers no study guide, practice exam, or even providing something that outlines the topics covered in the test. Just tells you to go over the learning objectives listed in each lecture slide which contains 5-7 bullet points of topics discussed plus terms to know. IMO, lectures were useless. Her tests are just questions she pulls from a question bank. To study, you just do GSS quizzes, previous quizzes, pre-class questions, and clicker questions. That is literally how you study. For the final, just basically told us to study ALL the material learned in the unit. If you know anything about biology classes in general, this is a ton of knowledge and material to cover. Grades homeworks fairly harsh and the clicker questions are how she counts for attendance. Doesn't curve, but does drop a midterm so that is nice.

Dr. Reaka was clearly very passionate about the subject matter which conveyed through her lectures. Most things needed for exams were on her slides but its definitely helpful to go to lecture. She posts study guides that have literally everything that could possibly be asked on the exam, so if you go to lecture at least sometimes and study for the exams its totally doable. (her slides also have a ton of pictures which is super helpful)

Dr. Rankin is extremely knowledgeable. She is also kind, caring, and has her student’s best interests at heart. However, her lecturing was not too engaging and her test writing was unreasonable for a 100 level course.

Class consisted of only lectures, which was mostly her reading off very dense slides. Occasionally, she would include her personal experience from her research, which I found really interesting. Most of the class skipped her lectures since they were dry, but I think it was valuable to go, since she would briefly mention something that would show up on exams. Every now and then she would become enthusiastic about certain species and she would become animated. Honestly, I wish her lectures consisted of her describing her research on various species.

Her exams were very difficult. Not only were the questions wordy and difficult to interpret, they frequently had answer choices of A, B, C, D. Two of the above, E. All of the above. Her exams were also given online in Lockdown Browser, so it was impossible to annotate the questions while taking the exam. She did allow for a notecard on Exam II, Exam III, and the Final. (Unfortunately, the averages for Exam I, II, and the Final were all still failing.) However, she offered a total 35 points of extra credit on exams, so that was really helpful!

Homework was given through the online textbook. There was a lot of it and it was not useful. It took 3 hours a week in addition to reading the textbook. Keeping ahead of the textbook reading was key. Yes, it was a lot of work, but it was necessary since it was difficult to absorb the content from the lectures.

Overall, Dr. Rankin is really a nice person. She wanted us to do well, but she just wasn’t used to teaching a 100 level course. The content for this course was extraordinarily interesting and that motivated me to read the textbook. It was also neat seeing how the content we learned in class was applicable to her real world experiments. If you’re trying to get into the Biology LEP, I would recommend taking an easier (safer?) professor, but if you want to push yourself and hear about the research application of BSCI160 info, Dr. Rankin is super cool.

My review probably will hold no value since I rarely ever went to class, but what I can say is that her lecturing style is incredibly boring (the whole reason I stopped going), but honestly that should not deter you from choosing her class. She’s a professor who actually cares a lot about the topic, so if you genuinely care then you’ll probably like the information taught, I personally couldn’t care for it. I will say she does care about the success of her students and her class average, she makes the most helpful study guides on earth and if you just make flash cards out of those then you’re good! But like I said, I really can’t talk much on her as a person since I never went to class, but from what I got from Canvas, she’s a pretty cool gal.

Professor Rankin is super nice and caring. She genuinely wants her students to succeed and she'll help you out if you're struggling. Other than that her class was not well put together. The homework each week wasn't consistent, there were a lot of them, they were pretty easy, but they seemed to be due on random days. I missed some homework assignments because I couldn't get into the flow of the work, so I'd check the homework page and suddenly there was an assignment due Monday that I missed because it wasn't there a few days ago. Her exams were also really hard. They were mostly multiple choice, with some short answer response questions. And they were still hard. People who guessed on every question could get a similar score (and not a good one) to people who took the notes and studied. The first exam went so poorly for the class as a collective, we got a complete do over. Her lectures were also really dry and I found it a real struggle to pay attention. The only thing that saved my grade from a D is the fact that she dropped the lowest exam score and curved (?) the other exams slightly.

this class when taught by her is extremely boring but you will still end up with a good grade. just be prepared to sit through her extremely boring lectures. Dr. Reaka seems to know a lot so if you are into ecology you might even like this class. Her study guides are super long and thorough and her tests are very fair. I never went to class and i got a B+ (and i wasnt really trying all that hard tbh i couldve gotten an A if i studied for her tests and showed up to class). Also shes a super nice lady.

Overally, I think Dr. Lee is a very good lecturer and does genuinely care about the learning of her students. Her lectures are very clear and easy to follow, and when able, she'll typically draw out some diagram or chart to make concepts easier to understand from the powerpoint. My only qualm with this class is that there are too many small assignments.  I know it was to encourage reading the textbook before class but half of bsci160 is common sense and the other half is what she would lecture on in class so it just seemed a bit pointless. Exams were very fair, and while there was no curve for this class, the averages were so high there was never a need. While I don't particularly vibe with her teaching style in terms of assignments and point distribution, if you like a class where the professor is very involved and you like having lots of small assignments to pad your grade instead of exams making up most/all of your grade, definitely take Dr. Lee.

Dr. Ngeve is very hard to understand and gives a good amount of homework. The exams are fair and relevant to the slides but she shoves too much information into one lecture and usually doesn't cover it all and then will make it your problem to learn at home.

Dr. Shapiro is very genuine and passionate about biology, especially birds and kale. Some of his lecture points were irrelevant to the subject, but he tries to keep the class engaged and fun. It is important to actually look at the lecture slides or you may be lost. The homeworks are unnecessarily difficult and long, and TAs will take off points for every little detail. The exams were not easy, but reasonable if you pay attention to the lecture slides and complete the homework. He tries to keep the exam grade median at around 75, so if it is lower he will add a curve. There are 3 midterms and a final, but he either drops the lowest midterm or downweights a midterm and the final (whichever gives the highest grade). Overall, I would recommend him for the intro to bio course, but more difficult classes should consider other professors.

One of my favorite professors. She is super responsive to feedback and changes the structure of exams/assignments relative to what students think about them. She gives a ton of extra credit and many opportunities for extra points. She allows a notecard on midterms and drops the lowest midterm grade. She genuinely wants us to do well. Brought a huge bag of candy to our exam that was on halloween. As for people saying they have trouble understanding her, I had no issue, and she provides all course materials so you can go through the slides on your own if you need.

Course: 
The course is divided into 3 units and progressively get harder/cover more material. Note-taking skills (not just copying down lecture slides) are essential. I highly recommend vocab cards for terms + concept maps for understanding connections. There is a discussion post due every week (lowest grade dropped) and homework packets due within 2-3 weeks of each other. One notecard is allowed on every midterm, the lowest midterm is dropped, and there are many resources to help you get ready for them. Slides and recordings of every lecture are posted. Clicker question participation is an easy 5% of your grade. There are so many extra credit opportunities in her class that it's ridiculous (individual EC assignments and EC exam questions) and you are very safe from falling lower than an A if you make the most of them. She gives a lot of support so take advantage of them!

Teaching style: 
Dr. Ngeve is very passionate about the subject she's teaching, which translates to her explaining things in detail so that students can fully understand and providing a wealth of extra resources about the topics covered and not covered in class. She genuinely wants you to understand what is being taught and encourages questions and conversations in class. She is very receptive to feedback and will adjust the course/assignments/tests to fit the students' needs (e.g. shortening the length of exams). Provides candy before each exam. A very nice woman who genuinely cares about her students. I highly recommend taking her and would love to take her again if I could!

Great Professor! She wants to help students by answering any questions you have and always provides feedback on assignments. There are 3 midterms with a cumulative final, the lowest midterm is dropped, and there is more than enough extra credit opportunities to get a good grade in the class. If information in the powerpoint slides is confusing, she adds the textbook chapters in which the information is available (which I highly recommend taking at least a skim of before the exam), and a list of the content that will be tested during the midterm! Again, she is a great professor who truly cares about her students!

This teacher will always be my favorite! She is great to take as a freshman as the class is not stressful and as long as you stay up with the work you can get a good great. Additionally there is more than enough extra credit in the class to maintain over an 100% for the majority of the semester. She lets you use a notecard for the exams so you have no reason to stress. Definitely take her!!!

I would definitely recommend this course as well as this professor. She made lectures enjoyable and was always willing to answer questions either inside of class or outside. There was also tons of extra credit offered throughout the semester which related to class content and was an easy way to get a few extra points while also studying for an upcoming exam. While I do not feel the content of this class was too hard to manage, all the credit goes to the professor for making the class as enjoyable as it was.

Lots of extra credit opportunities and easy assignments to boost grade. Midterms are decent; mostly multiple choice questions reviewed in class and short answer questions about the unit. Lectures are sometimes a little confusing and hard to follow, but she always opens for questions and answers thoroughly if there's anything that needs further explanation. All needed information (lecture slides, recorded lectures, exam review) is clearly laid out on the ELMS page, which has been very helpful.

Great professor, very understanding and flexible. This semester had many days when lecture was cancelled beyond the professor's control, which made the end of the semester feel extra rushed, but otherwise the semester was smooth and Dr. Ngeve is a great teacher. Exams are fair and most importantly she listens to students feedback.

I think she is one of the best professors I had this semester. It is a lot of lecture and I definetly had to go back and review a lot of the content, but the homework is fair and there is A LOT of extra credit opportunities. I would do all of them they can make all the difference in your grade. Overall a great semester and I definitely recommend her.

Dr. Ngeve is incredibly kind, knowledgeable, and very obviously cares about her student's learning and provides them ample resources to do well on exams. The point solutions are also very helpful when reviewed before tests. I can't stress how much I recommend taking Dr. Ngeve!

Dr. Ngeve is the epitome of a great professor. She is super passionate about what she teaches and this shows through her teaching and willingness to answer literally answer question. She will never make you feel dumb for asking any question and loves answering them. Her slides are helpful, but I always attended lecture because she explains it in a way that makes it much easier to understand than just reading the slides. I was able to end with above an 100% and I contribute that to all the study materials she provides and help she offers. I could not recommend her more :))

She is the sweetest and most understanding professor. She makes this course fun and makes the slides engaging. She gives so much extra credit to help boost your grade and you could easily end with an A+.
The course wasn't too challenging, you have access to a lot of resources. There is a lot of extra credit opportunities. Professor Ngeve is very kind and caring.

One of the nicest and caring professors that I have had. Tries very hard to teach the material, and while it was dry at moments, really cares about the learning. So much extra credit and practice is given, you really can't go wrong. For everyone who used to say things like "I wish grades didn't matter", take her. If you simply do your work and extra credit, you have a guaranteed A.

Dr. Ngeve is an incredible professor. She cares a lot about the students. She constantly checks to make sure people are keeping up with the lectures and gives good feedback on our weekly redigest (just watch a few videos and answer questions). She offers so many extra credit opportunities, and gives lots of extra resources to help with studying. There are weekly review sessions, so you don't get overwhelmed with the material. The material on these reviews and the redigests usually come up in the exams too. She also just gives great lectures. It's a lot of material, and definitely a fast paced class, but Dr. Ngeve makes it interesting. She tries to engage the class and she never reads off the slides, which I appreciate soooo much. She also lets you bring notes on an index card to all the exams (3 midterms and 1 final), and one of the midterm grades gets dropped. Definitely recommend Ngeve.

I really enjoyed Dr. Ngeve's class, she is very organized and the structure of the course is very easy to follow along. There are so so many extra credit opportunities to help boost your grade, and the assignments/homeworks are not extremely demanding. The course contains a lot of material, I mean it's a Bio class, lots of concept cramming, theories, and terms. Eventually, the bigger picture reveals itself and Bio becomes much more enjoyable as you can see the linearity of it all.

Dr. Ngeve is a great professor for this course. She evidently is passionate about what she teaches, and makes the lectures interesting as well. While at first it may be a bit difficult to understand her, it becomes super easy as the course goes on. In addition, she provides a significant amount of extra credit opportunities that, when utilized, have huge impacts on your success. She also allows you to utilize a notecard during all exams, proving how much she wants you to succeed in her course. I highly recommend Dr. Ngeve and would totally take her again.

This was one of my favorite courses, Ngeve's lectures move quickly but she is very informative and her slides are great. She also posts lots of recourses to help students and her TA's did the same. There are were also tons of extra credit assignments which was great. Exams were a bit packed but she took feedback from students very well and made adjustments. She is always willing to answer questions and she even lets students use a 3x5 2-sided cheat sheet on exams.
She is very good at explaining all topics. The Canvas page is very organized and I know what is expected. I felt like I learned a lot and there was a lot of support through the semester.

Supper kind and loves to engage students in her class/office hours (she hands out tons of candy). Lots of extra credit available and drops a whole exam so there is way less pressure. Take BSCI160 with her if you can!

I absolutely loved taking this class with Dr. Ngeve. She has an extremely engaging lecture style and provides both the lecture notes and lecture recordings for you to review before/after class. She does practice questions during class using point solutions and posts all of these prior to exams. Your lowest midterm score gets dropped and there are a ton of extra credit opportunities. She also lets you bring an index card with notes on it to each exam. Basically, it's very difficult to fail since there are a lot of opportunities to succeed and get extra help. I really appreciate the Thursday Night Redigests even though they can be long and there were many times I didn't feel like doing them, because they help a lot with exams. Sometimes exams take directly from the redigests or ULA Reviews, so actually completing them and reviewing them is super worthwhile. I found that there was a lot of support in this class and I really enjoyed the content and how she made connections. There are only 5 homeworks, they're kind of long but you usually have a week or two to complete them and she's very understanding about extending due dates. I would absolutely choose to have her as a professor again.
She offers a ton of extra credit and support throughout the semester. Would absolutely take her class again.

She is a really good professor that genuinely cares about her students. She is very easily reachable, and resolves any issues quickly. She gives a lot of extra credit and this course did not feel very stressful. She is great at teaching and does not just read off the slides. Her slides are also very informative, and she provides many useful examples. She brings candy and snacks to exams and allows people to have a notecard.
great professor but a lot of self-studying

Hey! Much like all of the other reviews here, Ngeve is genuinely such a good teacher. She's so supportive and there's absolutely no WAY you can fail this course. She gives so much extra credit, which not only helps your grade a TON, but also helps you better understand the material because it's relevant to what you are learning. While the slideshows are lengthy, it genuinely is not hard. The only thing is that the TNR's are a little long but as long as you space it out, everything is perfectly fine. TAKE HER - she'll make you genuinely interested in Bio and she's sosos sweet. I'll prolly have over a 100% at the end of this course.
Dr. Ngeve teaches very well and the lectures cover extensive amounts of information. The study guide for the exam has the list of all the topics and is very helpful.

I will say she is one professors that is up there that I favored. Cause she was very quick with grades and the slides were informational that will be helpful for exams. Also, she gave a lot of opportunities to get extra credit. Her grading wasn't the difficult it she would give as much point as possible and deduct the minimal points from the score. The only thing I was not a fan of were the exams. The exams are very nerve racking cause even though the slides were informational it is a lot of information that will be crammed into like 45-48 questions and some of them were like written response ones and you had to complete it in the class time frame. Which was only 1 hour and 45 min meaning you had to answer a couple word problems and like 35 multiple choice or true and false questions that took a lot of time and sometimes not even answer all the questions.

I would totally recommend Professor Ngeve for anyone taking this class. She's very helpful, friendly, and answered every stupid question I had. Overall, she does go through a lot of material in each lecture, and does keep track of participation, so you need to be going to class. However, she also posts recordings of lecture so if you do miss it, it's easy to keep up with the class. There is a lot of extra credit offered in the course, so even if you're not great with biology, there are plenty of opportunities to learn more and improve your grade. The homework load is reasonable, with one assignment about every two weeks. This tends to be a very large class, but Professor Ngeve makes time available if you need to talk with her, which I really appreciate. Loved Dr. Ngeve, learned a lot.
Awesome professor who wishes success on her students. Lots of resources to use such as ULA and TA's that are scheduled nicely.
I love her so much! Records all the lectures too <3

Professor Ngeve is a great professor and as long as you keep up with hte work and material you'll do well. Warning this course with Ngeve is a lot of material for each exam not something you can cram in one night to do well. Study a week - 4 days before an exam if you expect to do well.

This professor is responsive and helpful to answer questions. She provides many opportunities to boost your grade. Only thing is that the slides are not as informative and are a bit confusing to follow.

Dr. Ngeve is my favorite professor so far! She is very friendly and not intimidating which makes asking questions easy during lectures and office hours. She has plenty of review resources and uploads her slides. The recordings were also very helpful!

Dr. Ngeve was not my favorite professor. She was very disorganized in my opinion and half of the material was not taught well during her class. This class requires you to teach yourself a lot of the material and actively seek out help. I found that going over an assignment with a TA before it was due was very helpful. The way this class is structured it feel like information is being thrown at you and there is not enough time during class to digest it. The tests are extremely long and there is not enough time given for them especially the second exam. My suggestion would be to do well on the first test and do all of the extra credit. This class is not hard, but it is horribly structured. Dr. Ngeve does care about her students. In my opinion, she is not the most effective biology professor that I have had in my college education career.
Dr. Ngeve is a caring professor, but the class is not taught effectively. The class is not hard, but you do need to seek out help from the TAs in order to do well.
She is a great professor. Gives many extra credit opportunities and is very understanding. The lecture slides are long, so sometimes the entirety of a topic is not covered in class.

Course:
The course is divided into 3 units and progressively get harder/cover more material. Note-taking skills (not just copying down lecture slides) are essential. I highly recommend vocab cards for terms + concept maps for understanding connections. There is a discussion post due every week (lowest grade dropped) and homework packets due within 2-3 weeks of each other. One notecard is allowed on every midterm, the lowest midterm is dropped, and there are many resources to help you get ready for them. Slides and recordings of every lecture are posted. Clicker question participation is an easy 5% of your grade. There are so many extra credit opportunities in her class that it's ridiculous (individual EC assignments and EC exam questions) and you are very safe from falling lower than an A if you make the most of them. She gives a lot of support so take advantage of them!
Teaching style:
Dr. Ngeve is very passionate about the subject she's teaching, which translates to her explaining things in detail so that students can fully understand and providing a wealth of extra resources about the topics covered and not covered in class. She genuinely wants you to understand what is being taught and encourages questions and conversations in class. She is very receptive to feedback and will adjust the course/assignments/tests to fit the students' needs (e.g. shortening the length of exams). Provides candy before each exam. A very nice woman who genuinely cares about her students. I highly recommend taking her and would love to take her again if I could!

Good professor, good dude. Easy class overall, and it's really easy to get above a 85. His tests are tricky though, as 40/100 of the points are mcq questions that are always tricky. Not bad, always an option if you need to take his class.

Dr. Ngeve is super approachable! Although there is a lot of content she is always willing to help students out. She has pushed deadlines back multiples times and genuinely cares about her students and how they perform in her class. Her lecture notes are content heavyyy but the exams are mostly based of the slides. She also posts class recordings in case you miss. However there are attendance points so make sure you go to class. She gives so much extra credit that is actually helpful and useful for your learning in the class. I did almost every EC assignment and didn't really have to worry about my exam grades. There are 5 HWs, 3 exams (one is dropped) and the cumulative final. Overall this class can be a lot of work sometimes but Dr. Ngeve is awesome!

One of the best teachers I've had. Her style of teaching can be overwhelming but if you decide to time into the class and study for the midterms, you will succeed the class without a problem. She gives a ton of extra credit and lets you drop a midterm!

Dr. Ngeve is a great instructor. She is extremely knowledgeable, gives tons of extra credit, and truly wants all her students to exceed. The class does move very quickly so taking notes by hand can be challenging, but Dr. Ngeve was always happy to answer any questions or clear things up after class.

She is a good lecturer and provides many opportunities for extra credit. She does ask questions to the class where you can participate and test your understanding of the topics. I recommend looking over the ULA notes if you do not plan on attending as they are extremely helpful for preparing for the exam.

Dr. Shapiro is very passionate about this subject, but is kinda boring. Most of the class he would be standing up facing the board and doing his own thing, regardless if anyone listened to him. His exams and class is harder then the other professors and does not give out extra credit. He does drop your worst exam or down weight your final. Overall he seems like a nice guy making occasional funny jokes, but personally I'd skip his class all the time and still ended up fine.

Honestly, she is really nice, always wants to help, gives a lot of extra credit opportunities, and drops your lowest exam. Great class. Great Teacher. Only complaint is that sometimes she can go through material in class too fast, but she is the best.

If you are taking BSCI160, take Dr. Ngeve! Although her course can be content heavy, she does a really great job of breaking up the content. She posts all slides and recordings on ELMS at the beginning of the term. She also uses point solution questions to engage students during lecture and these are really great study tools. Her exams are very similar to the content she reviews in class and are pretty straightforward. Ngeve is also a really kind individual in general and is ALWAYS willing to help students and answer questions! She also gives a ton of extra credit opportunities, so there really is never a concern grade wise. Overall, I highly recommend Dr. Ngeve and enjoyed her class.
Offers many extra credit opportunities and encourages questions.

Keep in mind this class covers a lot of material so I would not recommend as a general education requirement. Lectures sometimes did not get through all the slides therefore you have to learn it at home. Exams were predictable and a notecard was allowed. Lowest mid term gets dropped which is helpful.  Professor Ngeve however is very caring and accommodating. She offers lots of extra credit to boost you grade and will always answer questions/explain concepts. Overall would recommend her and the class.

Professor Ngeve is really great with understanding where the students come from and she gives lots of extra credit work. I would say if you work hard and study, you can hit the A mark when it comes down to it.

Great lecturer. Exams are fair and she is accommodating. For example, one of our exams was a bit long for the amount of time we had, so she shortened that following exam. Take use of the extra credit assignments and start the hws in advance. They tend to be long, but the TAs are great help.

SHE IS THE BEST!!! she explains eveyrhting with details. Offers ALOT of extra credit, she l;ets you use an index card on the exam. Class participation do matter though so try to come to her lectures. Nothign bad to say about her at all
Dr. Ngeve really cares about students and their success. Take advantage of the extra credit work and you will have a buffer on exams so low(ish) stress.

She's super understanding, and sets straight to everyone that she wants everyone in the class to do well overall. From dropping the lowest exam, to the amount of extra credit opportunities, allowing aa notecard and such, she does everything she could in doing well. As long as you go over the lecture and the participation questions (point solutions) before the class, the exams aren't exactly terrible in terms of the content that is there.

This professor is great very organized, good communication practices and is very helpful to you passing the class. her ELMS has everything you need to pass exams (Literally questions and all lol). She also offers tons of extra credit opportunities and the chance to gain more knowledge. She is the best professor to use just do all the assignments before the exams, use your note card, do the extra credit and the TNRs you can't fail!

Dr. Ngeve is a bit tricky to understand and has a thick accent and goes extremely fast during lecture. She's very nice and frequently asked students if they have questions. The work load isn't too bad, and she lets you have an index card cheat sheet for exams.
She is nice and grades fairly. She also has time after class for any questions you might have

Dr. Ngeve really cares about her students understanding of the course material which is why she encourages asking questions during lecture. She is a nice teacher, but her teaching style is not good

Dr. Ngeve was one of my favorite professors this semester. While there is a bit of hw and it can be time consuming to take notes, I still really loved the class. There are so many extra credit opportunities it is insane. Notecards are allowed on all exams, and the lowest midterm is dropped. The final is completely open note and open internet. All around a great professor. She is very engaged in the material and wants her students to succeed. She has so many extra credit opportunities and other assignments to help boost your grade. She allows a notecard on all midterms and her canvas page is so organized with all material posted.

Honestly, an amazing class to take. Dr. Ngeve so obviously has a passion for teaching, and puts concepts in a way that is easy to comprehend! She is really nice and the class was pretty easy. There was not to much content covered and there is lots of extra credit. Exams are very fair. I think she assigned to much homework and the redigest(discussion) are too long.

She's knowledgable about the course material and she cares about her students performance. Her slides have a lot of content that you still need the textbook for to really understand her content however, she provides a lot of extra credit opportunity and only a few homeworks that do not take up too much time. Be prepared to study a lot though for the exams.
Excellent BSCI160 Professor. Do your work and you'll be fine.

Dr. Ngeve is truly very sweet and sincere, and actually cares about your learning. She provides many extra credit opportunities to help improve your grade and is a great lecturer. The only thing I would say is that there are so many lecture slides, that she often can't get through all of them in one class so you have to finish notes yourself outside of class, or she goes through the slides at a super fast pace. Additionally, there is a pretty good amount of outside work--the weekly TNR discussions can be time consuming. Overall though, I would recommend her. As long as you put the work in and pay attention in lectures, you should be able to succeed in her class.

Great professor. Has all the resources we need to succeed and gives a lot of credit to support our grade. She is very helpful when it comes to explaining concepts on things you are confused on. Highly suggest taking her for 160.

I had a really positive experience with Professor Ngeve. I took her for BSCI160 during the Fall 2023 semester and she is one of the most proactive professors that I've had. Her course is very content-heavy and the lectures do require you to actively pay attention, but she provides lots of resources to help you excel in the course. She is always willing to help you understand course material and hard to grasp concepts. The exams are fair game of everything that is gone over during lecture and the homework. She is a professor that is genuinely rooting for your success in the course and will do anything she can to help you get there, as long as you ask for assistance when needed.

It was a pleasure to take this BSCI160 with Dr. Ngeve. Although some of the work we had to do was time-consuming and the homework was harder than expected, the extra credit she gave us helped my grade immensely. Also if you did the TNR's (discussion posts) right, those helped boost my grade. The midterms were fairly easy since most of the questions were on the point solutions she goes over in class and she allows us to have a notecard during it. My advice is to look through her lecture schedule since there is everything on there and everything we need to start studying for exams. The lectures she has are recorded as well and it's useful if you did not get everything during class. All in all, I'm glad I had Dr. Ngeve as my BSCI160 teacher since this was the course I was less stressed about compared to the other classes I had this semester. She also dropped your lowest midterm which took the pressure off studying.

Great professor, this course is very content heavy so be prepared to move fast but Dr. Ngeve is amazing, provides many opportunities for extra credit, responds to emails very fast and genuinely cares for students. All slides are uploaded but sometimes not all slides are covered in lecture.
She's a good teacher and provides a lot of extra credit opportunities that help you understand the material.

Professor Ngeve is amazing!! if you put in the work and review all the resources she gives you, you will do well. she allows a notecard on the test and the final is completely open notes. her lectures are long and hard but the workload isn't too crazy and she gives great opportunities for EC and lots of resources to succeed. she cares about her students and is so nice!

I didn't think I'd like BSCI 160 but I did. Dr. Ngeve did a great job teaching! I was there was a MWF option, as the material is super dense, so it'd be nice to get it in smaller bites. She is a really nice and engaging professor. Professor Ngeve has been my favorite professor at UMD. She really helped me navigate the university and has made my first semester amazing. She is very smart as well and always willing to answer question. It is nearly impossible to fail her course because she gives tons of extra credit, support, and drops the lowest midterm.

So many opportunities to go beyond the scope of the course and demonstrate your passion for the subject. Dr. Ngeve is a great professor. She is extremely responsive both during and after class. She wants you to do well and provides an immense amount of material to learn and study from.

Easily one of the best professors I've ever taken here at UMD. They're very generous with extra credit, the lowest exam is dropped, and they go through their lectures at a good pace. In addition, she also has class participation on point solutions that factor into the exam so showing up to her lectures already helps a ton. The course was overall enjoyable and I can't recommend her enough for this class.

Professor Ngeve was a very fair choice to take BSCI60 with. I found it difficult at times to fully grasp the material, but the best way to do so is to watch her lectures online and take notes from what she says as opposed to the slide content. The slides she posts are often vague and not understandable, but combined with her monologue it makes perfect sense. She gives SO many extra credit opportunities which are often very easy, I had over 100% for most of the semester despite getting C's on the exams because of all of the extra credit. Over the semester, she gave 29 EXTRA CREDIT opportunities for a total of about 44 EC POINTS. DO NOT SLEEP ON THE EXTRA CREDIT. She counts clicker points for added participation at the end of the semester, and reviewing the clicker questions before each exam is so helpful (for exam 3, all of the exact clicker questions were on the exam). She drops 1/3 of the midterms and just announced that our final exam will be all MCQ and open book/open Google. You do need to put in a substantial amount of time and effort for this class though, it is not an easy A.

Dr. Ngeve is a great professor. She truly cares about her students and wants to see them succeed in her class. Her lectures are thorough and comprehensive, and she offers a bunch of extra credit opportunities. As long as you keep up with the assignments, you will do well in her class.

Dr. Ngeve is honestly a very good professor and a very nice person as well. She also makes sure to give you plenty of resources and materials for the units, and lots of extra credit opportunities to make up some points. The exams are not that bad, as long as you review the information, you are allowed a notecard, and the lowest exam is dropped. If you need help with anything, she's willing to give it and very flexible. I very much recommend her for this course!!

I think the professor did well in letting students know they are an open resource and is always willing to help and would like for students to succeed. She also gives a lot of extra credit which is always nice and the resources she gave like the ULA reviews were very helpful and many other resources are available in this course

Dr. Ngeve provides a lot of extra credit within the class so it's not that hard to raise your grade if not doing the best. The only thing that was difficult was sometimes it was hard to understand her with her accent.
Overall pretty good professor, the lectures can be lengthy and the other assignments are decently time consuming, but Dr. Ngeve supplies you with a lot of resources and extra credit to succeed.

Professor seems like a genuinely nice person. Lectures were very dense and sometimes we would not get through all the content during the class and she would expect you to cover the material outside of class. All lectures are recorded and slides are provided, but you do have to go to class since there are in-class participation points for clickers. The lowest midterm exam got completely dropped which was nice. Could also have a notecard on exams. Tons of opportunities for extra credit if you have time to do it. TAs are picky on homework grading. Overall would recommend it just because of the amount of extra credit and the lowest midterm being dropped. Also just was announced the final is a completely open book open internet and fully multiple choice.

I loved Dr. Ngeve's class. There is a lot of information and it can feel very overwhelming but Ngeve is always willing to help if you reach out. I can tell she clearly wants all of her students to succeed. She also offers so much extra credit that will save your grade if you do poorly on something. Highly recommend taking BSCI160 with her!!

She's great! Always asks students to ask questions and willing to stop lecture to clarify topics if people are confused. Also, she already has all of her lectures recorded and will have all of them posted on ELMS from the very beginning of the semester. 
Definitely take BSCI160 with her :)

She was very kind and was super understanding when it came to pushing back deadlines for assignments.
